document.text: You could make it faster by gyrocopter. But even by truck, its just overnight between Manhattan skyscrapers and Southside Virginia fields. Incidentally, the modern mechanized hay har vesting you see here cuts man-hours by about half. Its one of many reasons this area has growing reserves of manpower to staff new industries. Ask VEPCO for figures on the proven trainability and high per-dollar productivity of these workers. Ask, too, for plant site data and economic studies on this land of pleasant living and Southern production savings thats right on top of your richest markets. Write, wire or phone. J. document.text: Without nuclear power in the first seven months of 1974, fuel costs for Virginia Electric and Power Company customers would have been at least 45 million higher, Stanley Ragone, Vepco Senior Vice President, Power, said today. Surry Nuclear Power Station accounted for more than 25 per cent of the electricity generat ed by Vepco during the first seven months, just as projected in 1970, Mr. Ragone said. If we had had two fossil fuel plants at Surry instead of nuclear during that same period, the fuel cost would have been about 70 million. Allow ing for the higher initial costs of  nuclear facilities and the cost of operation, the net effect is a reduction in cost per kilowatt- hour of 2.5 mills or a quarter of a cent. The amount of oil required for two fossil fuel units at Surrey would have been tre mendous. Comparable oil - fired units would have consumed about seven millions barrels, or about 294 million gallons, to produce the same amount of energy generated by the two nuclear units. Mr. Ragone pointed out that during each month of the second quarter of 1974 Sury Unit 1 produced more electrici ty than any other nuclear unit in the world. Fuel costs will be reduced even more, Mr. Ragone said, as the units mature and account for an even greater output of kilowatthours. During July arid August, TJnit 1 at Surry recorded a 74.6 per cent performance level. Surry 2 during those two months performed at 68.4 per cent. The national average of performance by all nuclear units for the first six months was 53.7 per cent. Surry at 50.9 per cent was slightly below the national average for the same period. However, six month comparisons are not very significant, Mr. Ragone warn ed. We scheduled one unit at Surry out of service for maintenance during the Spring in order to avoid having it out of service during the Summer

text.snippet: million higher, Stanley Ragone, <mark>Vepco</mark> Senior Vice President, Power,

document.text: With electric service restor ed to nearly all customers,Vir ginia Electric and Power Com pany crews continued t h e i r round-the clock efforts to clean up and repair power facilities, and to determine the extent of damage caused by the flood. T. Justin Moore, Jr., Vepco president, said, It is impos sible at this time to estimate damage completely until all the mud, water and debris have been removed from the power stat- sions, substations, and trans mission and distribution lines that were in the path of the food. Current estimates of dam age, he said, Amount to 3.5 million and may exceed that, depending upon conditions at the Bremo Power Station. Despite a huge dike that protected the station during the C a m i l l e storm in 1969, the Bremo stat ion was inundated to a level of six feet above the turbine and boiler room operating floors. Damage to the system would have been far greater, Mr. Moore said, except for the strenuous efforts of Vepco per sonnel, many of whom worked from Wednesday through the week end with only a few hcthrs, rest, first in trying to prevent complete disruption and then in cleaning up and restoring serv ice. It is impossible to express just how proud we are of the work these men and women have done. All of us also owe tremen dous thanks to the men and wom en in municipal, county and state government services, the volunteer rescue squads, Nat ional Guard, Coast Guard, po lice and fire departments and to many others who joined forc es to aid the unfortunate, keep order and reduce the havoc of

document.text: when our demand is high. Another utility, one in Florida, perhaps, would schedule a maintenance outage of its unit in the Summer because its Winter load is heavier. The economic benefits of nuclear power to the consumer have grown rapidly, Mr. Ragone said, since we decided in the sixties to add nuclear powr to our generation mix. In 1973, for example, fossil fuels cost two to three times as much as nuclear to generate one kilowatt hour. The cost was  less than three-tenths of a cent for nuclear, six-tenths of a cent for oil, and seven-tenths of a cent for coal at all stations except Mt. Storm, W. Va. Because of the rapid in crease in cost for coal and oil during the past 12 months, fossil fuels now cost five to six times the cost of nuclear to generate a kilowatthour. Dur ing July of this year, the average cost of fuel per kilowatthour generated was less than three-tenths of a cent for nuclear. Nuclear generating stations initially cost more than conven tional fossil fuel stations, but the long-term economic benefit is most apparent because nuclear fuel costs are substanti ally less than fossil fuel costs. Vepco told the Atomic Energy Commission in a letter dated May 6 , 1974, that The conclusion that nuclear is the most economical alternative is still a valid conclusion in todays business environment. New water and air quality control guidelines proposed by the Environmental Protection Ag ency would bring the costs of fossil fuel power stations even more in line with the cost of nuclear facilities. Mr. Ragone also said that with North Anna Nuclear Units 1 and 2 in service for 1977, along with Surry 1 and 2, fossil fuel savings will amount to at least 200 million annually even after the increased investment is taken into consideration. These four units will relieve the nation of the need for more than 50 million barrels of oil or about 13 million tons of coal annually.

document.text: We THE PEOPLE of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union, establish justic, insure domestic tranqui lity, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare, and secure the bless ings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the United States of America. VEPCO Plans Rate Increase Virginia Electric and Power Company has announced plans to increase rates paid by the rural electric cooperatives, municipalities and one private utility the company serves on a wholesale basis. These wholesale customers, whose rates are under the jurisdiction of the Federal Power Commission FPC, were notified of the proposed increase in a letter which was sent yesterday by Robert S. Gay, Vepco manager of rates. In the letter, Mr. Gay said, The basic objective of our company continues to be to provide to all our customers the best possible electric service at the lowest practicable costs. However, our cost increases can no longer be absorbed. We feel it is essential, In order to continue to provide reliable service, that our rate for electric service to our rural electric cooperative, municipal and privately owned utility customers must be increased.

document.text: WALTER I. DOLBEARE. Vice-President in charge of Area Development for the Vepco System, who is a graduate of Brovin University with ?0 years of experience in the technical and operating branches of the public utility industry. During World War II he served on the staff of the Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific Fleet and now holds a commission as Captain, USNR. On his return, he was placed in charge of the new Area Development Department. He is at present chairman of the Area Development Committee of the Edison Electric Institute and of the Industrial Committees of the Virginia State Chamber of Commerce and the Richmond Chamber of Commerce. He is a member- also of the Board of Directors of the Virginia Travel Council.

document.text: voirs during off-peak load conditions. Future develop ment on the Cub Creek reservoir would include a 3,200 MW stream electric generating plant. Preliminary studies of applicant indicate an ultimate installed hydroelectric capacity of 3,575 MW at a cost of 1,700,000,000 exeluding Seneca-Taber and Melrose developments to be construct ed over a 16-year period. Alternative plans of develop ment would retain the basic multiple reservoir pumped storage concept but with certain upper reservoirs dis charging into different lower reservoirs and with corres ponding changes in NWL and TWL. The size, number, and type of units would be determined under studies to be conducted under the prelimi nary permit. The applicant proposes to market the power to its own customers, associat ed Electric Cooperatives, and municipally-owned electric uti lity systems in Virginia, North Carolina, and surrounding States. The applicant also proposes to exchange peaking power for off-peak and dump power with VEPCO and Appalachian Power Company. Any person desiring to be heard or to make any protest with reference to said applica tion should on or before June 9, 1975, file with the Federal Power Commission, Washing ton, D.C. 20426, a petition to intervene or a protest in accordance with the require ments of the Commissions Rules of Practice and Proced ure 18 CFR 1.8 or 1.10. All protests filed with the Commis sion will be considered by it in determining the appropriate action to be taken but will not serve to make the protestants parties to the proceeding. Any person wishing to become a party to a proceeding or to participate as a party in any hearing therein must file a petition to intervene in accord ance with the Commissions Rules. The application is on file with the Commission and is available for public inspection. Kenneth F. Plumb, Secretary. ________________ 4-17-4t Revival Being Conducted Now

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power j Company was notified today that the Atomic Safety and Licensing Board has authorized I the Nuclear Regulatory Com mission staff to issue an amended license allowing Nor th Anna 1 to be brought to final operational readiness. The decision amends the Boards earlier order permit ting fuel loading and will enable Vepco to bring the unit to Hot Sandby - a point where the reactor is ready to start producing power. W. L. Profitt, Senior Vice President for Power, said, We are pleased at the ASLB decision and will resume pre-operational testing at Nor th Anna as soon as the NRC issues the license. Profitt said the checkout of all systems and testing leading to hot standby status should take about two weeks from the time the license is issued. The Board clearly defined the issue in the recent hearing as arising from a disagreement between company personnel and commission staff over reporting procedures, Mr. Profitt said. We are confident that we and the NRC staff can eliminate any misunderstand ing over reporting require

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Companys local property tax payments in Virginia for this year are estimated at 24,252,000. Vepco pays these taxes, and they help localities, but the-- money comes from what customers pay us through mon thly bills,,r said David Heavenridge, director of taxes. This means that about 5 cents of each dollar our Virginia residential customers spent for electricity was used to pay local property taxes. Total state and local tax payments for the year are estimated at 78,667,000. That includes about 50 million in gross receipts tax paid to thè state and about 4 million paid to localities which impose licen se taxes. Most of the local property tax payments were due today. In a few cities, final payments are not due until Dec. 31. The Northern Virginia and Tidewater areas each accoun ted for about one-third the total local property taxes paid. Cen tral Virginia, including Rich mond, accounted for about one- fifth the taxes paid.  Prince William County had the largest tax bill for the year -

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Company today named Charles T. Snellings director of pur chases. He succeeds L. E. Davis, who retires April 1. Robert A. McKay, Jr., mechanical super visor at Vepcos Possum Point  power station, will succeed Snell ings as assistant to the purchas ing agent responsible for the pur-1 chase of fuels for electric steam 1 power generating stations. The 1 appointments are effective April 1 1.Snellings, formerly assistant to the purchasing agent, joined  Vepcos Purchasing Department in 1953 after several years with  the purchasing department of an engineering firm. His responsi bilities at Vepco have ben pri marily connected with the pur chase of fuels, principally coal, for the companys steam power ed generating stations. McKay, a native of Baltimore, Md., joined Vepco in 1940 as a statistician. He later served as efficiency engineer before he was named to his present post in 19- 61. He attended William and Mary College.

text.snippet: His responsi bilities at <mark>Vepco</mark> have ben pri marily

highlights.snippet: His responsi bilities at <mark>Vepco</mark> have ben pri marily

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Company today filed with the State Corporation Commission a request to add a limited number of gas customers. In a letter accompanying the requested changes, Vepco Executive Vice President William W. Berry said that the Company will be able to sell an additional 170,000 MCF thousand cubic feet of gas beginning August 1,1978. With the improved natural gas supplies ana Vepcos newly acquired storage capability this additional load will not have a detrimental effect on our existing customers, he explained. Vepco presently serves 118, 657 residential, commercial, and industrial customers in the Tidewater area of Virginia. The additional 170,000 MCF will allow the Company to serve approximately 2,000 new customers. We expect to serve a combination of residential, small commercial, and industrial customers, said Mr. Berry. The limitations will be on the amount of gas we have available to sell additional 170,000 MCF a year and the location of the new customers. We will not be installing new gas mains but we will connect new customers to existing mains.

text.snippet: accompanying the requested changes, <mark>Vepco</mark> Executive Vice President William

highlights.snippet: accompanying the requested changes, <mark>Vepco</mark> Executive Vice President William

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Company today filed an application with the Federal Power Commission for a substantial rate increase, re quested to be effective Jinuary 1, in an effort to gain a fair return on the investment necessary to serve its whole sale customers. In its application, Vepco requested an increase of about 30 per cent from 19 rural electric cooperatives and an increase of about 27 per cent from 21 municipalities and one private utility served on a wholesale basis. The request would yield a rate of return of 10.10 per cent on the companys investment necessary to serve the whole sale customers. This phase of Vepcos business accounted for about 11 percent of the total kilowatt hours sold by the company in 1973. Under the Federal Power Act, the Commission has the prerogative of permitting the rates to become effective as of January 1,1975, or postponing the effectiveness of the rates and ordering a hearing into their reasonableness. Any portion of the request im plemented on an interim basis, but not ultimately approved by the FPC, would be refunded with interest. E. B. Crutchfield, Vepco senior vice president, said that each month of delay in effective date of the requested rates would represent more than 1.5 million in revenue. Those revenues could never be recovered, Mr. Crutchfield said, The customers, on tne other hand, he pointed out, are protected because of the refund provision. He said for the test year ending  December 31, 1975, without a rate increase Vepco would earn a rate of return of 5.79 per cent from the cooperatives and 6,32 per cent from the municipalities and private utility. He pointed out that the companys testimony filed with the application would show that the company expenses have been the victim of severe inflation. In the past two years cost of

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Company has announced plans for an electrical outage for its customers in the Pamplin Area on Sat., Oct. 28, 1972 at 7 a.m. until approximately 10 a.m. Vepco customers affected will be on and near Highway Number 47 from the Pamplin Substation south to the inter section of Route 671 and east along Route 671 to the inter section of Route 663, near Dar lington Heights. This outage is to re-struct ure and increase the size of electric equipment serving that area.

text.snippet: until approximately 10 a.m. <mark>Vepco</mark> customers affected will be

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Company had the largest number of employees participating and raised the most money of any corporate employee team in the nation in the 1983 March of Dimes Walk Amer ica Campaign. The 5.386 walkers representing Vepco in the Walk America teamwalk on April 24 raised about 215,000 -- more than twice the amount contributed by the next highest utility. Among all types of corporations. Bank of America was second, with slightly less than 200,000, Last year-with more than 1.000 employees and their famiti raising 50,000 in the teathwalK  vepco contributed the largest amount of any utility in the nation. Vepcos effort this year was coordinated by Nancy Cross, director of office services, and Tim Sutor, senior office systems analyst, both in the management informa tion services department at the companys headquarters in Rich mond. Cross and Sutor will represent Vepco at the March of Dimes National Telethon against birth defects scheduled for July 3-4 in Los Angeles. The 21-hour telethon will feature such performers as George Buriis, Bob Hope, Sally Kellerman and Gregory Peek. An interview with Cross and Sutor ia scheduled to be broadcast on Monday, July 4, between 1050 and 1135 a.m. over television station WDCA, Channel 20, Washington, D.C.

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Com pany has been cited for its Bremo Power Station record of eight straight years without a disabling injury. Vepco President Erwin H. Will announced today that Edison Elec-, trie Institute has presented the com pany with the Safety Award of Merit. The Institute , is the trade as sociation of the electric industry. The award recognizes Bremo person nel for working more than a million and one-half man hours without a lost-time acicderat.

text.snippet: without a disabling injury. <mark>Vepco</mark> President Erwin H. Will

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Com pany has become a one-half billion dollar company, according to Vepco Treasurer S. E. Ratcliffe. RatclifFe said Vepco passed the 500,000,000 figure recently in the course of spending 50,000,000 on the companys construction program this year, He said the company expects to spend a record total of 70,000,000 next year in its expansion pro gram to keep pace with electrical demands of its present and future customers. The treasurer said soaring de mands for electricity in the post war years have made it necessary to more than triple the value of plant investments during that time. He cited some of the causes as the climbing use of electricity for air- conditioning, cooking, water heat ing, home heating, television, indus trial and commercial loads. Also, during the past ten years, nearly 300,000 new electric custo mers and 31,000 new gas customers in the Norfolk and Newport News area have boosted the customer

text.snippet: dollar company, according to <mark>Vepco</mark> Treasurer S. E. Ratcliffe.

highlights.snippet: dollar company, according to <mark>Vepco</mark> Treasurer S. E. Ratcliffe.

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Co. today reported net income available for common stock for the 12 months ending August 31.1974, of 69,958,000 or 1.39 per share on over 5 million more shares outstanding, com pared to 99,274,000 and 2.19 for the 12 months ending August 31,1973. Operating revenues for the 12 months ending August 31, 1974, were 641,442,000, com pared to 530,492,000 for the 12 months ending August 31,1973. A substantial portion of the increase in operating revenues, 91,838,000 for the 12-month period, w as due to the skyrocketing cost of fuel. Vepco receives no profit from the Fossil Fuel Adjustment Factor applied to customers bills. T. Justin Moore Jr., Vepco

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power ! Vepco is Company is seking volunteers  customers of from its Virignia residential volunteer for customers to participate in two through an Tim e-Of-Usage- TOU pro- months bül. grams. These two plans are part of  the State Corporation Commis-  sion - approved program designed te residential customers contol their bills and to temper the rate of growth in the demand for electricity, said W illiam W . Berry, j Executive Vice. President, j They are based on charging  higher rates for use of I electricity during peak periods of demand and lower rates when demand is less. Following the program carefully can lower a customers bill. In i - _ i addition, these programs have j-full year, said Mr. Berry.  the potential for shifting some j- i of the demand for electricity S from peak periods to off peak I periods - thus allowing better  use of the most efficient  generating equipment,1 Mr. Berry said. In the first plan one thousand volunteers will be billed according to both the amount of electricity used and the time of day its used. This will require installation of a special meter that registers the time of use, the customers peak demand, and the number of kilowatt- hours used. The key to saving on monthly bills depends on how much the customer can shift his use of electricity from on-peak, and more expensive hours, to the off-peak hours, said Mr. Berry. The second plan involves one thousand volunteers having electric water heaters. A special time-controlled meter that restricts operation of the water heater to off-peak periods will be installed.  This plan is recommended for customers whose electric water heaters have a large storage capacity and especially for those who have, a separate meter base on their homes from the previous special water heater rates. Since water heaters usually account for a j large share of total electric consumption this could result in savings for thé customer, said Mr. Berry.

document.text: Virginia Electric and ffower Company announced recently a revision of its conStrbciton program over the next .12 years. Stanley Ragone, Vepco Sen ior Vice President, said the action was taken because of 4 chance made in the eomgnys projected load growth through 1967 and a decision to withhold major expenditures on the Bath County Pumped Storage Pro ject untfl after the federal Power Commission issues a license. The company has adopted a most likely forecast of a 5.6 per cent conijpiounded annual growth rate in peak demand through 1967, down from the 6.5 per cent projection of one year ago. Mr. Ragone said, The revised forecast has been based on a gradual but modest recovery from the economic recession, continued conserva tion efforts by residential and industrial customers and fi nancial pressures that continue to affect all segments of the economy. The company has developed a range of peak load growth that ranges from a high of 6.5 per cent to a low of 4.5

document.text: Virginia E le c tric and Pow er Company is making long-range commitments to p urchase u ran  ium for conversion into fuel fo r nuclear power sta tio n s, in an effort to hold the lin e on future fuel costs. Vepco has negotiated a con tract for up to 9.9 m illion pounds of uranium a s uranium hexa- floride to be d eliv ered from 1975 through 1980. Stanley Rogone, Vepco vice president, said the com m itm ent calls for Vepco to purchase be tween 6.6 m illion and 9.9 m il lion pounds of uranium a s uran ium hexafloride a t a cost of around 90 m illion. The range allow s the company to make adjustm ents in the amount to be purchased if signi ficant changes occur in th e energy dem ands of custom ers on in nuclear fuel technology, Mr. Ragone said. document.text: VEPCO TO EXPAND STATION AT BREMO The board of directors of the Virginia Electric and Power Com pany has authorized the construc tion of a 22,000,000 addition to the companys power station at Bremo Bluff on the James River. The action was taken at a di rectors meeting held in Ports mouth, Va. Work on the new 150,000 kilo watt generating unit will start imt mediately. It is scheduled for com pletion by May, 1958. The new Bremo addition will be the same size as the first unit of the new station now being con structed by Vepco at Yorktown. Ground for the Yorktown station Was broken last month and the sta tion is scheduled to be completed in July, 1957. _

document.text: VEPCO salutes the Boy Scouts of America on their 40th Anniversary which occurs next week. These men of tomorrow have chosen a particularly tim ely f  f me about which to build their 1990 program i Strengthen the Arm of Liberty.  This theme should remind a 11 Am ericans that Liberty is not a static thing which, once created, endures forever. The stones of its foundation must be constantly repaired and replaced lest they crumble j J1111 k erosion of complacency and disregard of j fundamental rights. -  The VEPCOVIANS who live and work in Your Town, like its other good, substantial citizens, are proud of and share your interest in your local Boy Scout troops. VEPCO is proud to number among its employees many who are Boy Scout leaders-and many. more, who are former Boy Scouts.
